title: React vs Svelte × Windsurf Worth $3B × Typescript as Const × Layout Shift Tricks × More

right, this next question comes from
Jerry from Jersey. He says, "I've got a
two-part question. First, I love
Typescript most of the time, but why
doesn't TypeScript recognize that when
you use object keys, the keys are of
type key of my object? I know there are
workarounds like entries, but still it
feels odd." Second, which do you think
is worse using any or at TS ignore?
Okay, so for your first question, uh why
doesn't object keys get recognized as
the keys are of type key of my object?
Because in JavaScript, objects are
dynamic, right? Uh new properties could
be added to that object at any time. So,
TypeScript isn't going to just say
here's what the keys are because it's
built on top of JavaScript and those
objects are dynamic. The way you can get
this to work is if you tell Typescript
that that object is readon, meaning
those keys are never going to change,
then you can actually extract that type
out. So that's where the as const
keyword comes in in Typescript. So if
you create an object, you say as const,
that tells Typescript that you're it's a
it's a constant. It's read only. You're
never going to change the keys in there.
So if you do do object.keys, that will
actually come back as the correct type
because it knows that those keys are
never going to change. I use that quite
a bit in going back to the the JSON yeah
config, you know, I'll import that and
or I'll have an object that I've
imported from somewhere and I'll I'll
export it as const so that you can get
all of the keys from it really nicely.
Yeah, you get really good type
completion that way. Yeah, there's also
a bunch of like um like utility helper
functions that will do the key of and
extend it all. So you can also grab one
of those and and throw it in.
Definitely. Uh but the other question uh
what is worse using any or ts ignore?
What do you think? I think I think
they're both both of these are an
indication to the TypeScript compiler
that I don't want to worry about this or
I'm going to worry about this later. I
probably would say any because whenever
I see myself reaching for any, it's
because I don't want to take the time to
figure out what this type is or define
the type. If I'm using ts ignore, I am
explicitly saying, "Hey, Typescript
compiler, I know better than you or I'm
gonna fix this later, but it's a it's an
indicator that yes, I should come back
to this point." And typically with the
TS ignore, you can leave a little
comment as to like why you're ignoring
it. But yeah, any to me is I'm just I
don't want to take the time to define
this type. I agree. And any should not
be a escape hatch. Yeah, any exists
because there are some use cases in
Typescript where you literally want to
accept anything. You know, if you're
doing like a high order function, it
takes in a function with a whole bunch
of
arguments, you don't know what the
arguments are going to be because you're
you're wrapping a function. So, um you
can still of course infer all of that,
but in that case, you would would use an
any. Um but if you're using any as like
an escape hatch, I don't know. It's in
some cases maybe when you're you're like
moving over a codebase it's fine to
throw an any in there. That's what I'll
often do and then I'll go back and do a
search for it. But in in many cases if
you do not know you what something will
be you should probably be using an
unknown which will explicitly make you
check what the type is before you go
ahead and use it. So for example, if you
have a function that takes in an
argument and if you don't know if that
is going to be a string or a number or
any other type, you should set that as
unknown. Um, and that will make you
first check the type of it. You check if
it's a number and then you go ahead and
do math with it. You check if it's a
string and then you go ahead and and
concatenate it. With anything you just
anything goes, right? So that's a good
